Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: REU Site: Integrative approach to landscape evolution in a monogenetic volcanic field. San Francisco volcanic field, northern Arizona
Award.AbstractNarration:
The San Francisco volcanic field in northern Arizona is a natural laboratory for investigating the eruptive processes of cinder-cone volcanoes, the effects of eruption and erosion of these common but small systems on landscape forms, and the patterns and timing of volcanism. A multi-disciplinary team from Northern Arizona University, University of Arizona (Biosphere 2), and University of New Hampshire will offer an 8-week summer REU experience to 10 undergraduate students each summer, funded by the NSF Directorate for Geosciences. Two-three students from the first-year cohort will be invited to return in the second year to mentor new students, thus ensuring a long-lasting investment in research and experience in teaching other young scientists. The goals of the project are to provide all students with (1) a fundamental understanding of the relations between landscapes and basaltic volcanism, (2) an opportunity to construct a research project, with guidance from a mentor who will work alongside the student, (3) an understanding of how a research project is executed, from the initial research proposal to the final presentation and publication of results, (4) first-hand experience in interdisciplinary collaborations and research, and (5) a network of colleagues and mentors who will support the student's development as a scholar.

In the first two weeks of the program, students will learn theories of basaltic volcanism, Quaternary dating methods, and landscape studies. The first week will culminate in a two-day trip to Biosphere 2, an enclosed Earth system near Tucson, AZ. At the end of the second week, the student, with the assistance of his/her mentor, will write a research prospectus that will guide the goals and field or lab activities of the following five weeks. After a further 1-2 week study of a specific volcano, students in Quaternary dating projects will depart for the host lab to carry out their analyses. These students will continue to network with those who remain in Flagstaff throughout the summer, and, in the final week of the program, students and mentors will gather in Flagstaff to create posters that will model GSA/AGU posters. On the final day, students will join with participants in other REU programs at NAU for a research symposium. The posters will then be presented at GSA or AGU meetings that fall.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this project was to provide undergraduate students with the opportunity to study the evolution of volcanic landscapes in northern Arizona, and to advance knowledge of volcanic landscape development in this region. The San Francisco volcanic field presents an ideal natural laboratory to engage undergraduates in an integrated, interdisciplinary research program that couples volcanology and surface-process studies. The field area is a diverse mosaic of Quaternary volcanic features, most of which are not fully understood and have little or no age control. These gaps in scientific knowledge present an outstanding opportunity for a student-focused research program focused on combining volcanological and geomorphic lines of inquiry to examine rates and processes of landscape evolution. In the first project year, eleven students were accepted into the REU program and offered a range of field- and lab-based projects that took place over eight weeks in the summer of 2013. Each of the students was paired with specific mentors in the program. Two students, Amanda Houts and Kristiana Lapo, worked primarily with mentor Licciardi on projects focused on cosmogenic 3He surface exposure dating of late Pleistocene lava flows and cinder cones. Houts and Lapo both come from small colleges with limited opportunities and resources available for undergraduate research. A major outcome of this program has been to provide the participating students with a research experience that advances their professional development.

At SP Crater, results place a mean age of 59 ±1 ka on the SP flow and an age of 50 ±1 ka on the SP cone. These new data broadly agree with previously reported K/Ar, Ar/Ar, Ne-21 and He-3 age estimates, but lead to more precise exposure-age determinations than in prior work. At Strawberry Crater, results place a mean age of 57 ±1 ka on the lava flow and an age of 50 ±2 ka on the Strawberry Crater cone. Our new data provide the first reliable age for Strawberry Crater, and provide insight on potential differences in erosion rates and exposure histories between the lava flow and cone rim. We hypothesize that prior cinder cover on the SP and Strawberry cone rims, while no longer present at the sample sites, may have blocked incoming cosmic radiation in the past, accounting for the younger apparent age of the cone surfaces relative to the lava flow exposure ages.

In the final project year, Houts made the transition from undergraduate to graduate student researcher when she embarked on a M.S. program at the University of New Hampshire in September 2014. Due in large part to the experience and skills gained from her undergraduate research, Houts was already familiar with many of the techniques she is now using in her graduate work, which employs cosmogenic isotope exposure dating of volcanic and bedrock surfaces, and therefore builds directly from her earlier REU training. New skills gained by Houts as a graduate student include proficiency in wet chemistry isotope separation techniques, preparation of rock powder targets for major and trace element analyses, and data reduction and interpretation of 36Cl exposure ages. The earlier experience gained by Houts during her REU project was directly beneficial to her later activities as a graduate student researcher, and these opportunities have had a strong positive impact on Houts’ current and future academic pursuits and professional development.
